page.title: 11Horse-shoeing at Balmullo
page.content: A group of us went to see Mr. Wilson, the blacksmith, shoeing a horse. A horse needs new shoes about every six weeks. The shoes are all made in advance or mass produced and brought in. The most suitable shoe is chosen from a large range of sizes. The hoof is prepared by removing the old shoe and filing the hoof down. Mr. Wilson then heats the new shoe in a huge coal fire until it is red hot. It is then hammered into shape until it is just right for the hoof. The shoe is fitted on with 7 long nails which go right through the horse's hoof but don't hurt as there are no nerves there. Mr. Wilson then checks the shoe and tidies it up by using a claw hammer to break of the point of the nail, and filing it down.
